creditline: Gift of Thomas Lyon Owens in honor of Dennis Michael Jon
description: glossy, black mass throughout with yellow rectangle shape in LLQ; white triangular shape with humanoid figure standing in front of yellow shape, with gray torso and white legs; black and white circular shape at edge of yellow shape; white angular zig-zags emit from a roundish shape with linear elements and protrusions; inherent scratches in bottom center and in LRQ; black and white linear design in LRC; graduated, washy edge on right; ink splotches along the margins
markings: LRC, on right edge, in pencil: 9032A
provenance: Katherine T. Moos, St. Paul; Minnesota Museum of American Art, St. Paul, sold to Owens 1979; Thomas L. Owens, Minneapolis
signed: LRC, in margin, in pencil: William Wiley 62
text: This untitled oil on paper by William Wiley is most likely a preliminary study for a series of three large-scale oil paintings of 1961-62 he called “Columbus Rerouted.” Created when Wiley was completing his MFA degree at the California School of Fine Art in San Francisco, the series of paintings are the result of Wiley’s personal musings about Columbus Avenue, a major thoroughfare then undergoing reconstruction, which had forced him to find an alternate route to school. He began to consider what would have happened if Christopher Columbus had been similarly rerouted during his voyage to the New World (Western Hemisphere) and had not landed on Hispaniola, present-day Haiti. Like the larger works in the series, this oil on paper features Wiley’s characteristic blend of abstraction and representation, and includes such recognizable elements as a spoked wheel, a possible battle shield, a lightning bolt (a motif also reminiscent of a road surveyor’s staff), and a white triangle resembling the sails of a ship. In the end, Wiley’s imagery is a puzzle, a personal vocabulary of enigmatic symbols that resists precise interpretation.
title: Untitled
